------------------------------------------------------------

25.1 Purpose Ensures AI predictions are physically realistic and compliant with HVAC engineering best practices.

25.2 Validation Test Cases

Test 1 ‚Äî Impossible SAT Reset If climate zone = humid, SAT reset > 3¬∞F ‚Üí fail

------------------------------------------------------------

INCENTIVES & TARIFF LOGIC MANUAL

PART 1 ‚Äî INCENTIVE SYSTEM OVERVIEW, INCENTIVE TYPES

RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 1 ‚Äî PURPOSE OF INCENTIVE AND TARIFF MODELING

1.1 Purpose The goal of this manual is to define the engineering, financial, regulatory, and operational logic that an AI system must follow to correctly:

Identify applicable incentives Determine incentive eligibility Calculate incentive values Integrate incentives into financial modeling Prevent stacking errors Apply tariff rules Calculate bills accurately Evaluate tariff migration Align technical and financial constraints

This manual gives the AI the full ‚Äúmental model‚Äù of an incentive analyst + tariff engineer.

1.2 Incentives Covered in This Manual This manual covers:

SGIP (Self-Generation Incentive Program) Federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC) OBF (On-Bill Financing) CEFO (Clean Energy Financing Option) Energy rebates (kWh/therm-based) Lighting incentives HVAC incentives Controls incentives Retro-commissioning incentives EV charging incentives Demand response capacity payments DR event payments Federal/state/local tax credits Utility-specific rate-based adjustments Performance-based rebates (M&V)

AI must cross-reference incentives with:

Building type Technology category Climate zone Tariff Project location Customer sector (hospital, school, industrial, etc.)



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 2 ‚Äî INCENTIVE TYPES AND STRUCTURES

------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Incentive Type Classification All incentives fall into one of the following categories:

Category A ‚Äî Capacity-based incentives Category B ‚Äî Energy-based incentives Category C ‚Äî Performance-based incentives Category D ‚Äî Capital-cost incentives Category E ‚Äî Financing incentives Category F ‚Äî Tariff incentives Category G ‚Äî Tax incentives

AI must classify incentives into these categories because each influences modeling differently.

2.2 Capacity-Based Incentives Paid based on installed capacity:

kW (demand reduction) kWh (battery capacity) Thermal capacity for HVAC systems

Examples: SGIP base incentive ($/Wh) Utility kW reduction programs Some LED incentives ($/W reduced)

Capacity-based incentives affect CAPEX directly.

2.3 Energy-Based Incentives Paid based on kWh or therms saved.

EnergyRebate = Savings √ó Rate_per_kWh_or_Therm

Examples: Lighting kWh incentives Boiler therms incentives Chiller kWh measures VFD kWh measures

Energy-based incentives scale with modeled energy savings. AI must prevent overstated savings to avoid inflated incentives.

2.4 Performance-Based Incentives (PBI) Paid based on measured performance post-installation.

Examples: SGIP performance-based component DR performance payments Retro-commissioning DR performance Some advanced controls programs

AI must include: Performance degradation Weather normalization Load variability M&V rules

2.5 Capital-Cost Incentives These reduce CAPEX directly.

Examples: Lighting rebates HVAC rebates Chiller or boiler incentives EV make-ready funding

AI must avoid double counting with tax incentives.

2.6 Financing Incentives Examples: OBF (0% financing with utility review) CEFO (PG&E loan replacement) Low-interest financing PACE programs

Financing incentives influence cashflows, not CAPEX.

2.7 Tariff Incentives Examples: Demand charge holidays New TOU schedules for EVs Special rates for battery-backed load

Tariff incentives affect bill modeling.

2.8 Tax Incentives Federal Investment Tax Credit (ITC) State tax credits Accelerated depreciation (MACRS) Energy community adders Low-income area adders

AI must apply ITC basis rules.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 3 ‚Äî INCENTIVE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS

------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 General Eligibility Rules AI must evaluate eligibility based on:

Project size Customer type Technology category Location Climate zone Funding availability Load profile Program constraints

3.2 Required Data for Eligibility AI must capture:

Square footage Building type Tariff Historical usage Peak demand Gas usage (for therm measures) Technology list Permit requirements Site ZIP code Environmental conditions Equipment age Control system presence

3.3 Technology-Specific Eligibility HVAC incentives require: Actual HVAC equipment (RTUs, chillers, boilers) Verified operating schedule Verified savings model

Lighting incentives require: DLC-listed LEDs Minimum wattage reduction Valid control device category

Battery incentives require: Operational profile Cycle life Safety certifications (UL 9540/9540A) Eligible charging sources (for ITC)

EV incentives require: EVSE type Charger count Infrastructure readiness Correct electrical design

3.4 Customer Sector Eligibility Examples:

Hospitals ‚Üí SELA, SGIP equity resiliency, CEFO eligible Schools ‚Üí OBF eligible, most utility incentives Industrial ‚Üí often eligible for custom M&V Multifamily ‚Üí limited incentives Government ‚Üí special rate incentives

AI must check sector-based exceptions.

3.5 Location-Based Eligibility Certain incentives apply only to: Low-income areas Disadvantaged communities Energy Communities Wildfire zones (SGIP equity resiliency)

AI must determine location eligibility using ZIP code mapping.

3.6 Incentive Caps Incentives often capped by: Project size Project cost Customer type Annual utility budget Individual incentive maximums

AI must enforce caps strictly.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 4 ‚Äî SELF-GENERATION INCENTIVE PROGRAM (SGIP)

------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 SGIP Overview SGIP is one of the most important incentives for battery projects. It provides $/Wh incentives that decrease in blocks (steps) as program funds are deployed.

4.2 SGIP Categories General Market Equity Equity Resiliency Large Storage Small Storage Thermal Storage

AI must determine which category applies.

4.3 SGIP Base Formula SGIP_incentive = Battery_kWh √ó incentive_rate_step

Typical incentive rates:

General Market Step 1 ‚Üí ~$0.50/Wh Step 2 ‚Üí ~$0.45/Wh Step 3 ‚Üí ~$0.40/Wh Equity ‚Üí ~$0.85/Wh Equity Resiliency ‚Üí ~$1.00+/Wh

Rates vary ‚Äî AI must reference program data.

4.4 SGIP Step-Down Logic Steps decrease as funding is consumed. AI must:

Check current step Apply correct rate Ensure project does not exceed step capacity

4.5 SGIP Performance-Based Incentive (PBI) PG&E and SCE offer PBI components.

TotalPBI = kWh_cycled √ó PBI_rate_per_kWh √ó PerformanceFactor

PerformanceFactor determined by: Availability Degradation Dispatch strategy

AI must include PBI in multi-year financial model.

4.6 SGIP Equity Resiliency Eligibility requires: Low-income census tract Fire-threat district Critical resilience facility (hospital, emergency facility, etc.) Lack of redundancy

AI must evaluate eligibility using location + facility type.

4.7 SGIP Fire Zones Mapped through CAL FIRE. AI must apply wildfire threat tiers correctly.

4.8 SGIP Rules for ITC Stacking If SGIP considered a ‚Äútaxable rebate‚Äù ‚Üí reduces ITC basis If considered performance payment ‚Üí not reduce ITC basis

AI must apply correct rule per program guidance.

4.9 SGIP Project Caps Max incentive: 2 MWh per project $5M per customer (varies)

AI must enforce caps.

4.10 SGIP Charging Source Requirement To maintain high SGIP eligibility, battery must follow rules: Discharge cycles must be documented Charging source (PV vs grid) may affect ITC

AI must align with ITC rules when needed.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 5 ‚Äî ON-BILL FINANCING (OBF)

------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 OBF Overview OBF is a 0% financing mechanism through the utility bill.

Eligibility constraints: Simple payback must be within the program-defined limit Loan term cannot exceed projected savings Customer must be in good standing

5.2 OBF Loan Term TermMonths = SimplePaybackYears √ó 12 or limited by OBF program rules.

5.3 Cashflow-Positive Requirement NetAnnualSavings must exceed annual loan payments. If not ‚Üí OBF denial.

5.4 Eligible Technologies OBF commonly supports: Lighting HVAC Controls Boilers VFDs Sometimes batteries (rarely)

5.5 OBF Modeling LoanPayment = LoanAmount √ó (r_monthly / (1 ‚àí (1+r_monthly)^‚àíTermMonths))

Because OBF typically uses 0% interest, r_monthly = 0. Thus LoanPayment = LoanAmount / TermMonths.

AI must apply this special case.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 6 ‚Äî CLEAN ENERGY FINANCING OPTION (CEFO)

------------------------------------------------------------

6.1 CEFO Overview CEFO is PG&E‚Äôs successor to OBF and supports financing for: Batteries HVAC upgrades Lighting Controls EV charging Solar (in some cases)

Key rule: CEFO mirrors past OBF loan duration if customer had a previous OBF.

6.2 CEFO Loan Constraints CEFO requires: Project to remain cashflow positive Customer repayment through utility bill Loan size capped at OBF-equivalent max or custom limit Loan duration limited to the same months as customer‚Äôs previous OBF OR Loan duration based on technology category

AI must enforce: CEFO_loan_duration = previous_OBF_months

6.3 CEFO Payback Logic Because CEFO replaces CAPEX with a loan: CEFOPayback = LoanTermYears // informational only CashflowCheck = NetAnnualSavings ‚â• AnnualLoanPayments

If constraint fails ‚Üí CEFO rejected.

6.4 CEFO vs ITC If project includes battery, ITC may apply. Loan does not reduce ITC basis. AI must maintain consistent CAPEX basis rules.

6.5 CEFO vs SGIP CEFO + SGIP stacking allowed. AI must offset CAPEX by SGIP before applying loan where appropriate.

------------------------------------------------------------

INCENTIVES & TARIFF LOGIC MANUAL

PART 2 ‚Äî ITC, TARIFFS, STACKING, INTERACTIONS, VALIDATION

RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 7 ‚Äî FEDERAL INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT (ITC) ‚Äî DETAILED MODELING

7.1 Overview of ITC The Federal Investment Tax Credit provides a percentage of qualifying project costs as a tax credit. AI must follow the tax rules governing:

Eligible costs Charging-source requirements for batteries Adders Depreciation interaction Clawback risks

7.2 ITC Eligibility Summary ITC applies to: Solar PV Solar + storage Standalone energy storage (post-IRA, subject to final guidance) Microgrid controllers (limited)

Battery eligibility requires: Predominantly renewable charging OR Standalone storage eligibility under Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) provisions

AI must check proper eligibility based on commissioning year.

7.3 ITC Rate Base ITC = 30% Adders: Domestic Content: +10% Energy Community: +10% Low-income adder: +10‚Äì20% for certain project types

Maximum ITC can reach 50% under certain conditions.

7.4 ITC Basis ITC_Basis = EligibleCAPEX ‚àí DisallowedIncentives

Disallowed incentives include: Grants Upfront rebates Cash incentives Some utility incentives (depending on classification)

AI must never include: Soft costs that are specifically excluded Non-energy improvements Financing fees

7.5 ITC Calculation ITC_Amount = ITC_Basis √ó ITC_Rate

7.6 Depreciation Interaction MACRS Depreciation basis must be reduced by 50% of the ITC.

DepreciationBasis = ITC_Basis √ó (1 ‚àí 0.5 √ó ITC_Rate)

AI must apply MACRS over 5 years with appropriate bonus depreciation if allowed.

7.7 ITC Clawback Modeling If renewable charging requirement violated: IRS may demand repayment proportional to violation time.

Under IRA, standalone storage avoids this requirement.

AI must check system-specific rules.

7.8 Timing Rules ITC is applied in Year 0 (investment year). AI must discount properly in NPV calculations.

7.9 ITC and SGIP Interaction Rules vary: If SGIP rebate considered a ‚Äúrebate‚Äù ‚Üí reduces ITC basis If SGIP considered a ‚Äúperformance payment‚Äù ‚Üí not reduce ITC basis

When uncertain, AI must assume conservative option.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 8 ‚Äî UTILITY TARIFF STRUCTURES (TOU, CPP, RATINGS)

------------------------------------------------------------

8.1 Tariff Components Tariffs include: Energy charges ($/kWh) Demand charges ($/kW) Fixed charges ($/month) Minimum charges Seasonal schedules TOU periods CPP adders Environmental surcharges Public purpose programs Demand ratchets

AI must model each component.

8.2 Time-of-Use (TOU) Tariffs TOU tariffs vary hourly or seasonally.

Typical TOU periods: On-peak Part-peak Off-peak Super-off-peak (rare)

AI must apply the correct period for interval billing.

8.3 Demand Charges Demand charges apply to highest interval demand in a cycle.

DemandCharge_annual = DemandChargeRate √ó AnnualPeak

If tariff includes multiple demand components (non-coincident, on-peak): AI must evaluate each.

8.4 Tiered Tariffs Some tariffs charge based on kWh tiers. AI must: Track cumulative kWh Apply correct tier rate

8.5 Critical Peak Pricing (CPP) On CPP days, energy price is extremely high (e.g., $1/kWh). AI must: Detect CPP days Apply CPP adders Allow battery DR or arbitrage to reduce CPP exposure

8.6 Ratchet Tariffs Ratchet tariffs impose demand charges based on a percentage of annual peak.

RatchetDemand = max( DemandCurrentMonth , RatchetPercent √ó Peak_prev_11_months )

AI must enforce ratchet constraints.

8.7 Facilities Charges Fixed charges apply regardless of use. AI must add: MonthlyFixedCharge √ó 12

8.8 Minimum Charges If minimum consumption or minimum bill applies: AI must report minimum charge value.

8.9 EV-Specific Tariffs Utilities may offer special tariffs for: Workplace charging Fleet charging DCFC sites EV TOU rates

AI must evaluate tariff eligibility for EV infrastructure.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 9 ‚Äî TARIFF MIGRATION MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------

9.1 Purpose of Tariff Migration Battery, HVAC optimization, EV charging, or multi-measure efficiency may enable switching to a more favorable tariff.

TariffMigrationSavings = BaselineBill ‚àí NewBill

AI must recompute bills accurately.

9.2 Tariff Eligibility Conditions Tariff eligibility may depend on: Customer type Load factor Max demand thresholds Presence of solar or battery Annual consumption

AI must confirm eligibility before migration.

9.3 Full Bill Reconstruction AI must build full utility bill using:

Interval kWh √ó TOU rates Peak demand √ó demand charges CPP adders Fixed charges Minimum charges Taxes and fees Seasonal multipliers

BaselineBill and NewBill must be computed separately.

9.4 Reconstructing Demand Charges DemandCharge_New = Peak_new √ó DemandChargeRate Where Peak_new is post-project adjusted peak.

9.5 Reconstructing Energy Charges EnergyCharge_New = Œ£( kWh_new(t) √ó Rate(t) )

9.6 Computing Tariff Migration Benefit BenefitMigration = BaselineBill ‚àí NewBill AI must add this to annual savings.

9.7 Guardrails AI must not: Assume tariff switching without verifying eligibility Ignore increased fixed charges Ignore seasonal VTOU differences Ignore demand ratchets in new tariff



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 10 ‚Äî INCENTIVE STACKING RULES

------------------------------------------------------------

10.1 Purpose Incentives must be correctly stacked to avoid double-counting or violating program rules.

10.2 Compatibility Matrix (Simplified) SGIP + ITC ‚Üí allowed, basis rules apply CEFO + SGIP ‚Üí allowed, SGIP reduces CAPEX before loan SGIP + OBF ‚Üí allowed CEFO + ITC ‚Üí allowed ITC + lighting rebates ‚Üí allowed ITC + HVAC rebates ‚Üí allowed CEFO + OBF (simultaneous) ‚Üí NOT allowed Multiple utility rebates for same fixture ‚Üí NOT allowed

AI must enforce this compatibility logic.

10.3 Priority Ordering for Stacking Stack incentives in this order:

Step 1 ‚Äî Capacity-based incentives (SGIP, DR capacity) Step 2 ‚Äî Energy-based incentives Step 3 ‚Äî Capital-cost incentives Step 4 ‚Äî Tax incentives (ITC) Step 5 ‚Äî Financing incentives (OBF/CEFO) Step 6 ‚Äî Tariff incentives

AI must reduce CAPEX accordingly before calculating ITC.

10.4 ITC Basis Reduction Rules If incentive is: Rebate ‚Üí reduces basis Performance-based ‚Üí does NOT reduce basis Grant ‚Üí reduces basis Loan ‚Üí does NOT reduce basis

AI must classify incentives correctly.

10.5 Double-Counting Prevention AI must NOT: Add SGIP and also count kWh savings for same energy reduction mechanism Stack lighting incentives from two utilities Use chiller replacement incentive twice Apply EV incentives from overlapping programs

10.6 Stacking Failure Cases Stacking fails if: Combined incentive > 100% CAPEX Loan violates cashflow positivity ITC basis improperly calculated Project uses incompatible incentives

AI must reject invalid stacking.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 11 ‚Äî MULTI-MEASURE INCENTIVE INTERACTIONS

------------------------------------------------------------

11.1 Why Interaction Matters HVAC, lighting, batteries, EVs, and DR interact. Incentives must follow technology-specific rules even when measures overlap.

11.2 HVAC + Controls + Lighting Lighting may reduce cooling load ‚Üí reduces HVAC incentive eligibility. Controls may reduce reheat, not cooling load. HVAC retro-commissioning incentives require specific measures.

AI must avoid inflating savings incentives.

11.3 Battery + DR + SGIP SGIP incentivizes capacity DR incentivizes performance ITC incentivizes capital Battery must follow all scheduling, charge-source, SOC rules

AI must ensure: SGIP capacity incentive not confused with DR event revenue DR energy not confused with arbitrage

11.4 EV + Battery + Tariff Migration Battery may reduce EV demand ‚Üí reduces demand charge exposure Tariff may change based on EV load ‚Üí increases incentive eligibility

AI must recompute all incentives after tariff switch.

11.5 Whole-Building Combined Packages Large retrofits often apply: Lighting HVAC Battery Controls EV infrastructure

AI must keep incentive accounting separate per measure category, then sum totals.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 12 ‚Äî INCENTIVES VALIDATION MATRIX

------------------------------------------------------------

12.1 Purpose Validation framework ensures that incentive calculations follow correct rules and are physically, financially, and regulatorily valid.

12.2 Validation Tests

Test 1 ‚Äî Eligibility If technology not eligible ‚Üí reject incentive.

Test 2 ‚Äî Basis Calculation If ITC basis > CAPEX ‚Üí error.

Test 3 ‚Äî SGIP Category If customer not in equity territory ‚Üí reject equity category.

Test 4 ‚Äî Stack Limit If combined incentive > 100% CAPEX ‚Üí reject.

Test 5 ‚Äî Tariff Migration If tariff switching is impossible ‚Üí reject.

Test 6 ‚Äî DR Performance If DR shortfall expected ‚Üí reduce PBI or reject DR program.

Test 7 ‚Äî HVAC/LTG Interactive Effects If HVAC interactive effect included incorrectly in incentive ‚Üí adjust or reject.

Test 8 ‚Äî Duplicate Incentives If two incentives overlap for same fixture or system ‚Üí reject second incentive.

12.3 AI Response to Failures AI must: Report failure explicitly Explain reason Suggest alternative incentive paths Apply conservative fallback assumptions



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 13 ‚Äî AI GUARDRAILS FOR INCENTIVE & TARIFF LOGIC

------------------------------------------------------------

13.1 Never Hallucinate Incentives AI must only reference incentives that actually exist. AI must never invent: Program names Incentive rates Customer categories

13.2 Never Assume Eligibility AI must verify: Customer type ZIP code Building type Measure type Tariff Load profile

13.3 No Excessive Incentive Claims AI must reject:

100% CAPEX coverage Incentive stacking beyond allowed Lighting incentives for HVAC savings HVAC incentives for lighting savings

13.4 Weather & Tariff Guardrails AI must apply correct seasonal tariffs. AI must not assume year-round flat rates. AI must always check TOU period alignment.

13.5 Financial Consistency If incentive changes tariff, AI must recompute entire bill. If incentive reduces CAPEX, ITC updated accordingly.

13.6 Transparency Rules AI must output: All incentive assumptions Stack order Basis calculations Eligibility confirmations Warnings Uncertain conditions



------------------------------------------------------------

LIGHTING MODELING MANUAL

PART 1 ‚Äî FOUNDATIONS, FIXTURE TYPING, LOAD MODELING

RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 1 ‚Äî PURPOSE OF LIGHTING MODELING

1.1 Purpose This manual defines the engineering logic and mathematical methods required to model lighting energy use, lighting retrofit savings, lighting controls impacts, HVAC-lumens interactions, ballast behavior, fixture mapping, and end-use interactions. It provides rules for how AI must identify baseline lighting loads, predict retrofit savings, and produce consistent financial outcomes based on lighting improvements.

1.2 What Lighting Modeling Supports ESCO-grade project scoping Retrofit package creation Lighting audit estimation Lighting-to-HVAC interaction modeling Daylighting synergy Controls evaluation Financial savings and incentive evaluation Multimeasure stacking with battery, HVAC, and controls Lighting schedules inference Interior + exterior lighting identification

1.3 AI Behavior Requirements AI must: Never hallucinate fixture types or wattage Request missing fixture counts or area sizes when critical Follow deterministic engineering relationships Respect ballast behavior Prevent unrealistic savings (>75% whole-facility unless proven) Apply HVAC interaction adjustments correctly Use climate zone guidance for lighting-HVAC coupling Be conservative when hours-of-operation uncertain Explain all reasoning in text



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 2 ‚Äî LIGHTING SYSTEM TYPES AND IDENTIFICATION

------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Interior Lighting System Types Fluorescent T5, T8, T12 CFL LED tubes (ballast-bypass, ballast-compatible) LED retrofit kits LED panel lights Metal halide high bay High-pressure sodium Incandescent Halogen Decorative luminaires Track lights Downlights

2.2 Exterior Lighting System Types Parking lot pole lights Wallpacks Floodlights Bollards Streetlights Canopy fixtures Area LEDs

2.3 How AI Identifies Lighting Types

Based on: Building type (office ‚Üí troffers, warehouse ‚Üí high bay, parking lot ‚Üí HID) Square footage Ceiling height Lighting density per ASHRAE Historical internal EverWatt project database Fixture counts if provided Interval load ‚Äúovernight spikes‚Äù (indicating exterior lighting) Photo evidence if available

AI must never: Assume LED by default Ignore exterior lighting Apply indoor hours to outdoor loads Confuse HID with LED retrofits

2.4 Mapping Lighting Technologies to Wattages

AI must use realistic baseline wattages:

Troffers: T12: 96W T8: 68W T5HO: 54W LED panel: 30‚Äì40W

High bay: Metal halide: 400W‚Äì1000W HPS: 250‚Äì400W LED high bay: 150‚Äì300W

Exterior pole lights: HID: 250‚Äì400W typical LED retrofit: 70‚Äì150W

Downlights: CFL: 26‚Äì42W LED: 12‚Äì18W

AI must apply correct fixture-to-watt conversions.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 3 ‚Äî HOURS OF OPERATION MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Hours of Operation (HOO) Hours greatly affect savings. AI must estimate HOO when not provided using building type:

Office interior: 50‚Äì70 hours/week School interior: 40‚Äì60 hours/week Hospital: 24/7 for critical areas Warehouse: 2-shift or 3-shift depending on operation Retail interiors: 70‚Äì100 hours/week Exterior lights: dusk-to-dawn (~4,000‚Äì4,500 hours/year)

3.2 Inferring Hours from Interval Data AI must detect lighting baseload in interval data: If nighttime usage > daytime-off usage ‚Üí exterior load If early morning spikes with occupancy ‚Üí interior lights If flat baseload at night ‚Üí mixed HVAC/lighting if warehouse or industrial

3.3 Schedule-Based Hours If schedule known: HOO = occupied_hours √ó lighting_profile_factor

3.4 Conservatism Rules If hours uncertain, AI must assume lower hours to avoid overstated savings. AI must not assume 4,000 hours/year for interiors unless specified.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 4 ‚Äî LIGHTING ENERGY MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 Basic Lighting Energy Equation LightingEnergy = FixturePower √ó Hours √ó FixtureCount

Where FixturePower = input watts including ballast losses.

4.2 Ballast Factor Fluorescent wattages vary with ballast. Actual fluorescent power = NominalWattage √ó BallastFactor BallastFactor = 0.77‚Äì1.18 depending on ballast type.

AI must adjust fluorescent wattage accordingly.

4.3 LED Driver Power LED wattage includes: LED electrical load Driver conversion loss Thermal losses

AI must assume typical LED driver efficiency = 85‚Äì90%.

4.4 Fixture Efficacy Efficacy = lumens per watt AI may use efficacy ratios to determine lumen equivalence but must not mix lumen modeling with energy modeling unless doing daylighting analysis.

4.5 Interactive Effects (HVAC Impact) Lighting produces heat. Reducing lighting reduces cooling load but increases heating load in some climates.

CoolingInteractionSavings (kWh) = LightingEnergyReduction √ó CoolingFraction √ó HVAC_COP_Adjustment

HeatingInteractionPenalty (therms) = LightingEnergyReduction √ó HeatingFraction / BoilerEfficiency

AI must estimate cooling and heating fractions based on climate zone and building type.

4.6 Whole-Building Savings AI must apply interactive adjustment:

NetElectricSavings = LightingSavings_kWh ‚àí HeatingPenalty_kWh_equivalent

CoolingReduction_kWh

NetThermSavings = LightingThermPenaltyReduction

RULE: Lighting retrofit always reduces kWh Heating therms may increase depending on climate



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 5 ‚Äî LIGHTING RETROFIT MEASURE MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 LED Tube Retrofits (TLEDs) Types: Ballast-compatible Ballast-bypass Hybrid

Savings_TLED = LightingEnergy_old ‚àí LightingEnergy_new ¬± HVAC interactions

AI must verify ballast factor and driver type.

5.2 LED Panel Retrofits PanelWattage ‚âà 30‚Äì45W Replaces 2x4 fluorescent troffer (68‚Äì96W)

Savings_Panel = (OldW ‚àí NewW) √ó HOO √ó Count Adjusted for HVAC interactions.

5.3 High Bay LED Retrofits HID_to_LED savings substantial: 400W MH ‚Üí 150W LED 1000W MH ‚Üí 300W LED

AI must enforce: High bay LED cooling interaction is high in climate zones with cooling dominance.

5.4 Exterior Lighting Retrofits Exterior hours typically 4,200‚Äì4,500 hr/yr. Savings significant: 250W HID ‚Üí 70W LED 400W HID ‚Üí 120‚Äì150W LED

Exterior lights have no HVAC interactions.

5.5 Specialty Lighting Retrofits Track lighting Decorative/museum lighting Halogen spotlights

AI must adjust wattages using fixture libraries.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 6 ‚Äî CONTROLS MODELING

------------------------------------------------------------

6.1 Occupancy Sensors Savings_Occ = FractionTimeVacant √ó LightingEnergy_old

Typical values: 20‚Äì40% savings in intermittently occupied spaces.

AI must ensure occupancy profiles match building type.

6.2 Daylight Harvesting Savings_Daylight = DaylightZoneFraction √ó LightingEnergy √ó DaylightEffectiveness

Where: DaylightZoneFraction = area within 15‚Äì20 ft of windows DaylightEffectiveness = 20‚Äì60% depending on glazing

6.3 Timeclock Scheduling Savings_Sched = IncorrectlyScheduledHours √ó FixturePower √ó Count

AI must detect after-hours usage from interval data patterns.

6.4 High-End Trim High-end trim reduces maximum lighting output. Savings_Trim = ReductionFraction √ó LightingEnergy

High-end trim ranges from 10‚Äì30%.

6.5 Luminaire-Level Lighting Controls (LLLC) LLLC combines occupancy, daylight, high-end trim. Typical savings: 35‚Äì60%.

AI must not exceed 60% controls savings even under ideal conditions.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 7 ‚Äî LIGHTING EFFICIENCY MEASURE BUNDLING

------------------------------------------------------------

7.1 Bundling Rules Bundling lighting retrofits with controls amplifies savings. However, savings must follow proper order:

Lighting retrofit reduces base load. Controls savings must be applied to post-retrofit load, not baseline. HVAC adjustments apply after lighting reduction. Interactive heating penalties must be applied last.

TotalSavings = LightingRetrofitSavings

ControlsSavings(onNewLoad)

7.2 Exterior + Interior Bundling Exterior savings unaffected by interior hours. Interior + exterior must be summed.

SECTION 9 ‚Äî LIGHTING CLIMATE ZONE ADJUSTMENT

9.1 Cooling-Dominant Climates Reduce HVAC cooling load by: CoolingInteractionSavings ~ 10‚Äì20% of lighting savings

Heating penalty is small.

9.2 Heating-Dominant Climates Minimal cooling interaction Heating penalty significant: HeatingPenalty = LightingReduction √ó HeatingFraction

9.3 Mild Climates Both cooling and heating interactions exist but moderate.

------------------------------------------------------------

MULTI-MEASURE STACKING MANUAL

PART 1 ‚Äî FOUNDATIONS, INTERACTIONS, AND STACKING FRAMEWORK

RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 1 ‚Äî PURPOSE OF MULTI-MEASURE STACKING

1.1 Purpose This manual defines the engineering and financial logic necessary to combine multiple energy efficiency measures (EEMs) ‚Äî including lighting, HVAC, battery storage, EV charging, building controls, and demand response ‚Äî into a unified modeling framework.

The goal is to allow AI to: Combine measures without double-counting savings Respect interactive effects between systems Determine stacking priority Find optimal bundles Calculate combined economics Identify conflicts Explain interactions clearly Avoid infeasible combinations

1.2 Measures Considered This manual covers:

Lighting retrofits Lighting controls HVAC controls VAV/VVT/CAV optimization RTU retrofits Chiller + boiler upgrades Battery storage (peak shaving, arbitrage, DR) EV charging infrastructure Demand response programs Building automation system upgrades Retrocommissioning

1.3 AI Responsibilities AI must: Identify compatible measure combinations Reject incompatible combinations Apply correct modeling order Apply interaction factors Avoid double counting Model combined economics Adjust measure savings when interacting Provide clear measure-level and total savings breakdown Flag measures that become unnecessary due to others



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 2 ‚Äî MULTI-MEASURE INTERACTION PRINCIPLES

------------------------------------------------------------

2.1 Why Measures Interact Energy measures interact because:

Lighting reduces cooling load Lighting increases heating load HVAC resets reduce fan + compressor energy HVAC commissioning affects cooling loads Battery reduces peak but does not reduce actual kWh EV load increases peak and kWh DR participation affects battery availability Controls flatten profiles Boiler reset interacts with VAV reheat CHW reset interacts with economizers

2.2 Measure Interaction Types Type A ‚Äî Synergistic (1+1 > 2) Example: CHW reset + SAT reset + static pressure reset These produce compound savings.

Type B ‚Äî Overlapping (1+1 < 2) Example: Lighting + SAT reset, where lighting reduces cooling load, shrinking SAT reset savings.

Type C ‚Äî Conflicting Example: HVAC load reduction needed for DR while SAT reset also active; some combinations reduce effective savings.

Type D ‚Äî Independent (1+1 = sum) Example: Exterior lighting + chiller optimization.

AI must classify interactions among all measures.

2.3 Interaction Effects on Savings Total savings must follow:

TotalSavings = Sum(Savings_i) ‚àí OverlapLosses

SynergyGains

2.4 Interaction Priority Interactive effects must be applied in hierarchical order:

Lighting ‚Üí HVAC ‚Üí Controls ‚Üí Battery ‚Üí DR ‚Üí EV

Reason: Lighting affects HVAC HVAC affects controls Controls affect battery operation Battery affects DR EV affects tariff and DR

AI must use this exact chain.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 3 ‚Äî MEASURE ORDER OF OPERATIONS

------------------------------------------------------------

3.1 Why Order Matters Incorrect measure ordering leads to double counting or misallocation of savings. AI must always stack measures in a deterministic sequence.

3.2 Order of Operations Correct order is:

Step 1 ‚Äî Compute baseline loads Step 2 ‚Äî Apply lighting retrofit Step 3 ‚Äî Apply lighting controls Step 4 ‚Äî Apply HVAC optimization Step 5 ‚Äî Apply HVAC equipment upgrades Step 6 ‚Äî Apply battery modeling (shaving + arbitrage + DR interaction) Step 7 ‚Äî Apply EV charging load Step 8 ‚Äî Apply DR program modeling Step 9 ‚Äî Recalculate tariff (including rate migration) Step 10 ‚Äî Compute combined savings Step 11 ‚Äî Apply incentive stacking Step 12 ‚Äî Compute total financial metrics Step 13 ‚Äî Validate

AI must never deviate from this order.

3.3 Why This Order Works Lighting modifies HVAC loads HVAC modifies comfort + reheat Controls modify HVAC behavior Battery modifies electricity bill but not HVAC loads EV modifies demand and TOU costs DR interacts with battery and HVAC Tariff migration depends on aggregated results



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 4 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN LIGHTING AND HVAC

------------------------------------------------------------

4.1 Lighting ‚Üí HVAC Interaction Lighting reduction lowers cooling demand and increases heating demand.

CoolingInteractionSavings = Lighting_kWh_reduction √ó CoolingFraction / HVAC_EER_equivalent

HeatingInteractionPenalty = Lighting_kWh_reduction √ó HeatingFraction / BoilerEfficiency

AI must compute these interaction effects.

4.2 How Lighting Affects HVAC Savings Lighting reduces: Reheat Cooling load Supply air temperature reset potential

Lighting affects HVAC measures: SAT reset CHW reset Economizer operation Static pressure reset Reheat reset

AI must shrink HVAC savings accordingly.

4.3 Interaction Ranges Cooling-dominant climates ‚Üí strong interaction (10‚Äì20% savings tied to lighting load) Heating-dominant climates ‚Üí small or negative interaction Mild climates ‚Üí moderate interaction

4.4 Validation If combined lighting + HVAC savings > 50% of total building load ‚Üí unrealistic, flag.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 5 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN HVAC MEASURES

------------------------------------------------------------

5.1 HVAC Measure Synergies HVAC measures often reinforce each other:

Static pressure reset ‚Üí lowers fan energy SAT reset ‚Üí reduces cooling + reheat CHW reset ‚Üí improves chiller efficiency Boiler reset ‚Üí reduces heating therms Economizer ‚Üí reduces compressor kWh

5.2 Synergistic Savings Example If SAT reset and static pressure reset applied: FanSavings_spreset = cubic CoolingSavings_satreset = linear CombinedSavings = synergy factor applied AI must apply synergy factor ~1.05‚Äì1.15

5.3 Overlaps Few HVAC measures overlap: SAT reset reduces cooling, which limits CHW reset effect Static pressure reset reduces airflow, limiting SAT reset savings Boiler reset reduces reheat availability

AI must subtract overlap.

5.4 HVAC + Controls Measures Controls such as DCV reduce HVAC runtime, impacting CHW reset savings, SAT reset savings, and reheat savings.

AI must avoid double counting.

5.5 Validation If HVAC stack savings > 30% of building consumption ‚Üí likely unrealistic unless poor baseline controls.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 6 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN HVAC AND BATTERY

------------------------------------------------------------

6.1 Battery ‚Üí HVAC Battery storage affects electricity cost profile, not HVAC kWh consumption.

AI must NOT apply HVAC load reduction due to battery.

6.2 HVAC ‚Üí Battery HVAC schedules heavily influence peak demand. Peak shaving must consider HVAC-driven peaks.

6.3 Interaction Logic If HVAC reduces peak demand significantly ‚Üí battery peak shaving potential decreases.

BatteryPeakShave_new = min(Battery_kW, Peak_new ‚àí TargetPeak)

AI must adopt the new reduced baseline peak for battery modeling.

6.4 HVAC ‚Üí DR HVAC can provide DR load shedding. Battery+HVAC DR synergy possible.

AI must model coordinated dispatch during DR.

6.5 Validation AI must ensure: HVAC savings do not reduce kWh eligible for battery arbitrage Battery DR does not create HVAC comfort issues



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 7 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN BATTERY AND EV LOAD

------------------------------------------------------------

7.1 Battery ‚Üí EV Battery can mitigate EV demand impact. Battery may reduce: EV demand charges Transformer overload Peak impact

AI must calculate battery-based peak shaving on EV loads separately.

7.2 EV ‚Üí Battery EV charging increases site peak ‚Üí increases battery dispatch demand.

Battery must have enough: Power (kW) Energy (kWh) SOC reserves

7.3 Combined Load Modeling EV_peak_new = EVPeak_before_batt ‚àí min(Batt_kW, EVPeak_before_batt)

Battery delivers: kWh_EV_support = min(Batt_kWh, EV_kWh_needed_for_peak)

7.4 Validation If EV load exceeds battery rating by >3√ó ‚Üí battery insufficient as mitigation.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 8 ‚Äî INTERACTION BETWEEN DR AND BATTERY

------------------------------------------------------------

8.1 DR ‚Üí Battery DR event reserves must be prioritized over arbitrage.

Battery must start at sufficient SOC pre-event:

SOC_required = (Committed_kW √ó EventDuration) / E_usable

8.2 Battery ‚Üí DR Battery may supply full DR curtailment if appropriately sized.

AI must check: Battery_kW ‚â• committed_kW Battery_kWh ‚â• committed_kW √ó event_duration

8.3 Interaction Constraints Battery DR reduces arbitrage cycles. Battery DR may reduce available peak shaving.

AI must update savings accordingly.

8.4 Validation If battery used for DR, arbitrage savings must be reduced in modeling.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 9 ‚Äî CROSS-MEASURE OPTIMIZATION LOGIC

------------------------------------------------------------

9.1 Purpose AI must evaluate all measures together to form an optimal package.

9.2 Multi-Measure Objective Choose measure bundle that maximizes: Net present value Payback IRR Demand reduction Carbon reduction Customer-specified goals

9.3 Optimization Process For each measure i: Compute standalone savings Compute interactions with all previous measures Apply incentives Apply stacking rules Compute financial metrics

AI must iterate through all valid combinations.

9.4 Dominance Rule Measure A dominates measure B when: A has higher NPV A meets constraints B meets A has lower CAPEX A offers larger savings

AI must eliminate dominated measures.

9.5 Multi-Measure Feasibility AI must drop measures that: Offer small marginal savings Are redundant after previous optimizations Conflict with customer goals Exceed budget or panel capacity



END OF PART 1

------------------------------------------------------------

MULTI-MEASURE STACKING MANUAL

PART 2 ‚Äî FORMULAS, EXAMPLES, VALIDATION, AI LOGIC

RAW STRUCTURED ENGINEERING TEXT

------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 10 ‚Äî FULL MULTI-MEASURE STACKING FORMULAS

10.1 Purpose of Stacking Formulas Stacking formulas ensure all measures are evaluated in correct sequence and that savings are neither understated nor overstated.

10.2 General Stacking Formula TotalSavings = Œ£(BaseSavings_i √ó AdjustmentFactor_i) ‚àí OverlapLosses

SynergyGains

Where:

BaseSavings_i = savings of measure i if applied alone AdjustmentFactor_i = factor adjustment after previous measures OverlapLosses = reductions due to overlapping effects SynergyGains = additional gains from measure interaction

10.3 Example Adjustment Factors Lighting retrofit reduces cooling load ‚Üí reduces HVAC cooling savings. AdjustmentFactor_HVAC = 1 ‚àí CoolingInteractionFraction

If lighting reduces cooling by 15%: AdjustmentFactor_HVAC ‚âà 0.85

10.4 Overlap Losses Overlap occurs when two measures target the same energy stream.

Examples: SAT reset and CHW reset overlap on cooling DCV and economizer overlap on ventilation air HVAC DR and HVAC optimization overlap on airflow

OverlapLoss = min(Savings_A, Savings_B) √ó OverlapCoefficient

10.5 Synergy Gains Certain measures increase the effectiveness of other measures.

Examples: VFD + Static Pressure Reset SAT reset + Chilled Water Reset Battery + DR

SynergyGain = Savings_A √ó Savings_B √ó SynergyCoefficient

Typical SynergyCoefficient = 0.05‚Äì0.20

10.6 HVAC-Lighting Interaction Formula HVAC_Interaction_AdjustedSavings = LightingSavings √ó InteractionFactor(CZ, building_type)

Where InteractionFactor is based on climate zone.

10.7 Battery + HVAC Integration Formula BatteryPeakShave_afterHVAC = min(Battery_kW, Peak_afterHVAC ‚àí TargetPeak)

Battery savings recalculated after HVAC measures applied.

10.8 EV + Battery Integration Formula Battery supports EV loads: EVPeakReduced = EVPeak ‚àí min(Batt_kW, EVPeak)

AI must re-evaluate EV-augmented peak.

10.9 DR + Battery Integration Formula Battery DR energy: DR_EnergyRequired = Committed_kW √ó EventDuration

Battery must supply this before arbitrage is re-modeled.

ArbitrageReduction = (min(DR_EnergyRequired, ArbitrageEnergy)) √ó Spread



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 11 ‚Äî DETAILED REAL-WORLD MULTI-MEASURE EXAMPLES

------------------------------------------------------------

11.1 Example 1 ‚Äî Office Building (VAV + Boiler + Lighting + Battery)

Baseline: Lighting: 250,000 kWh/yr HVAC Cooling: 450,000 kWh/yr Heating: 25,000 therms/yr Peak: 350 kW

Measures: Lighting retrofit (LED) Lighting controls HVAC static pressure reset CHW reset Boiler reset Battery (100 kW / 400 kWh)

Stacking:

Step 1 ‚Äî Lighting Retrofit LightingSavings = 250,000 ‚àí 120,000 = 130,000 CoolingReduction = 130,000 √ó 0.12 = 15,600 kWh HeatingPenalty = 130,000 √ó 0.02 = 2,600 kWh equivalent (or therms based on boiler)

Step 2 ‚Äî Lighting Controls (post-retrofit) LightingControlsSavings = 120,000 √ó 0.25 = 30,000 kWh

Step 3 ‚Äî HVAC Optimization Cooling load reduced by lighting: HVACSavings_adjusted = 450,000 √ó 0.12 √ó 0.85 (reduced by lighting interaction)

Step 4 ‚Äî Battery Modeling Peak after HVAC = 350 ‚àí 40 = 310 kW BatteryPeakShave = min(100, 310 ‚àí target) Arbitrage adjusted because HVAC reset reduces daytime load

Step 5 ‚Äî DR Modeling DR kW now smaller because lighting + HVAC reduce baseline load.

Total system savings must sum properly.

11.2 Example 2 ‚Äî Hospital (CHW plant + Steam + Lighting + DR + Battery)

Complex interactions: Lighting reduces cooling ‚Üí reduces chiller load HVAC resets reduce heating ‚Üí reduce steam demand Battery DR must reserve SOC, reducing arbitrage DR stacked with HVAC resets Battery DR + hospital peaks overlapping

AI must detect: Lighting + CHW reset + CW reset synergy Lighting + boiler reset overlap Battery DR conflict with peak shaving

11.3 Example 3 ‚Äî School (RTUs + Boiler + Lighting + Controls) Lighting retrofit reduces RTU cooling HVAC resets smaller because RTUs are packaged DX Boiler heating penalty moderate Demand reduction from RTU staging improves battery value

AI must stack: Lighting Controls RTU advanced logic Battery

11.4 Example 4 ‚Äî Industrial Site (High Bay + EV fleet + Battery) High bay lighting retrofit reduces warehouse cooling load EV charging increases peak Battery mitigates EV load Battery DR reduces arbitrage potential

AI must simulate battery behavior with EV fleet arrivals.



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 12 ‚Äî MULTI-MEASURE VALIDATION MATRIX

------------------------------------------------------------

12.1 Purpose Ensures multi-measure models avoid double counting, incorrect stacking, or impossible combinations.

12.2 Validation Test Cases

Test 1 ‚Äî Lighting + HVAC If lighting + HVAC savings > 50% total consumption ‚Üí fail unless HID-heavy facility.

Test 2 ‚Äî HVAC + Battery If HVAC and battery both reduce peak for the same interval ‚Üí allow only ONE savings source.

Test 3 ‚Äî DR + Battery If DR reduces peak and battery also reduces the same peak ‚Üí apply DR first, battery second or vice versa depending on goal. Avoid double counting.

Test 4 ‚Äî EV + Battery If battery reduces EV peak, EV must not count DR reduction separately unless EV curtailment occurs.

Test 5 ‚Äî Battery DR + Arbitrage If battery used for DR, arbitrage reduced proportionally. Failure to reduce ‚Üí fail.

Test 6 ‚Äî Boiler Reset + Lighting If boiler reset savings > heating load after lighting retrofit ‚Üí fail.

Test 7 ‚Äî Controls + HVAC If combined controls + HVAC savings exceed thermodynamic limits ‚Üí fail.

Test 8 ‚Äî Tariff Migration If tariff switch triggered by HVAC + lighting + battery combination ‚Üí must rebuild entire bill. If not ‚Üí fail.

Test 9 ‚Äî Incentive Stacking If incentive stacking > 100% of CAPEX ‚Üí fail.

Test 10 ‚Äî Comfort or Safety If combination violates HVAC standards ‚Üí reject.

12.3 AI Response to Failures Reject combined measure Flag failure Recommend revised combination Ask for missing data Enforce conservative assumptions



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 13 ‚Äî COMPLETE MULTI-MEASURE OPTIMIZATION ENGINE LOGIC

------------------------------------------------------------

13.1 Objective Find the measure bundle that maximizes user goal (e.g., ROI, NPV, DR revenue, demand reduction).

13.2 Optimization Algorithm

Step 1 ‚Äî Identify all feasible measures based on system type Step 2 ‚Äî Calculate standalone savings Step 3 ‚Äî Apply stacking order Step 4 ‚Äî Recalculate loads Step 5 ‚Äî Apply battery modeling Step 6 ‚Äî Apply DR modeling Step 7 ‚Äî Apply EV loads Step 8 ‚Äî Apply tariff migration Step 9 ‚Äî Compute incentive stacking Step 10 ‚Äî Compute final savings and financial metrics Step 11 ‚Äî Check all validation rules Step 12 ‚Äî Produce sorted bundle recommendations

13.3 Dominance Pruning Remove measure bundles that: Underperform across all metrics Violate constraints Cost more and save less

13.4 Customer-Goal-Based Prioritization If user prioritizes: Demand Reduction ‚Üí HVAC + battery prioritized DR Revenue ‚Üí Battery + HVAC DR Energy Savings ‚Üí Lighting + HVAC optimization Carbon Reduction ‚Üí Lighting + HVAC + heat pump retrofits Capex Minimization ‚Üí Controls + lighting

13.5 Bundle Explanation AI must provide: What measures included Why included Why others excluded Savings breakdown Financial impacts Risks Uncertainties



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 14 ‚Äî AI GUARDRAILS FOR MULTI-MEASURE STACKING

------------------------------------------------------------

14.1 Core Rule AI must NOT double count savings under any circumstances.

14.2 Lighting Guardrails Lighting savings cannot fully compound with HVAC savings Lighting + controls must apply controls to post-retrofit load Exterior lighting savings do not impact HVAC

14.3 HVAC Guardrails HVAC savings cannot be added twice for overlapping measures HVAC comfort limits always enforced HVAC reset applicable only to VAV/CHW systems

14.4 Battery Guardrails Battery does not reduce HVAC consumption Battery does not reduce lighting consumption Battery savings only impact cost, not physical HVAC load Battery DR must reduce arbitrage savings

14.5 EV Guardrails EV peak cannot be reduced twice (battery + DR) unless distinct intervals EV diversity must remain realistic EV DR only eligible in fleet or controllable environments

14.6 DR Guardrails DR must never be double counted with peak shaving DR baseline must be validated DR revenue must match performance

14.7 Tariff Guardrails Tariff migration must be fully recomputed Seasonal TOU must be enforced Ratchet logic must be applied

14.8 Incentive Guardrails No overlapping incentives Correct stacking order Correct basis adjustment



------------------------------------------------------------

SECTION 15 ‚Äî SAMPLE MEASURE STACK OUTPUT FORMAT

------------------------------------------------------------

AI must output:

SECTION 1 ‚Äî PURPOSE OF THE APP ARCHITECTURE

1.1 Purpose This manual defines the complete system architecture for a unified, AI-driven energy modeling and optimization application that integrates:

Battery storage HVAC optimization Lighting retrofits EV charging Demand Response (DR) Tariff modeling Incentive modeling Multi-measure financial stacking AI explanation + decision-making

The architecture must support:

Sales enablement Engineering modeling M&V-ready calculations Battery sizing HVAC scope design Lighting audits EV load modeling DR qualification Tariff migration analysis CEFO/OBF/SGIP/ITC integration Large-scale portfolio modeling Internal consistency and validation

1.2 Objective Build a system where: A non-engineer (salesperson) can enter simple inputs AI fills in missing technical pieces Deterministic engines run calculations AI orchestrates interactions Final outputs match engineering-grade accuracy

1.3 Responsiblities of the Architecture Enforce safety Ensure accuracy Detect missing data Apply conservative fallbacks Coordinate modules in correct order Prevent double counting Explain rationale in plain English Provide validated results

SECTION 2 ‚Äî SYSTEM MACRO-ARCHITECTURE

2.1 High-Level Layer Diagram (text)

Layer 1: User Interface Layer 2: AI Orchestration Engine Layer 3: Deterministic Modeling Engines ‚Äì Battery Engine ‚Äì HVAC Engine ‚Äì Lighting Engine ‚Äì EV Engine ‚Äì DR Engine ‚Äì Tariff Engine ‚Äì Incentive Engine ‚Äì Multi-measure Stacking Engine Layer 4: Data Access Layer Layer 5: Validation & Safety Layer Layer 6: Explanation Engine Layer 7: Reporting Layer Layer 8: Memory & Learning Layer (if allowed)

2.2 Architectural Philosophy The system follows a ‚ÄúHuman ‚Üí AI Brain ‚Üí Deterministic Models ‚Üí AI Explanation‚Äù loop.

2.3 Module Separation Each module must be independent: Battery engine does not contain tariff logic HVAC engine does not contain incentives logic Lighting engine does not resolve battery SOC DR engine does not compute tariffs

2.4 Interaction Bus Interactions between modules occur through the AI orchestration layer, not through direct module-to-module calling.

3.4 Data Quality Scoring AI must assign data quality scores: High (interval present) Medium (bills only) Low (building type only)

SECTION 7 ‚Äî INTERNAL DATA STRUCTURES & REPRESENTATION

7.1 Purpose The app must represent all modeling inputs, outputs, intermediate values, constraints, and interaction variables in consistent, structured forms. AI must operate on these structured representations, not free-form text.

7.2 Core Data Structures The system uses several key data structures:

SECTION 10 ‚Äî VALIDATION LAYER DESIGN

------------------------------------------------------------

10.1 Purpose Validation layer ensures that model outputs follow constraints, physics, tariff rules, incentives rules, and multi-measure stacking rules.

10.2 Validation Categories Technical validation Financial validation Regulatory validation Safety validation Stacking validation Comfort validation

10.3 Technical Validations Battery duration > DR duration Battery kW <= inverter kW HVAC savings <= HVAC load Lighting savings <= lighting load EV load <= electrical capacity DR baseline valid Tariff valid

10.4 Financial Validations NPV not extreme Payback > 0 Annual savings not negative (unless representing cost increase for EV-only modeling) Loan payments meet CEFO or OBF rules ITC basis correct Incentive stacking <= 100% CAPEX

10.5 Regulatory Validations Tariff eligibility correct SGIP category correct ITC eligibility correct CEFO loan duration matches previous OBF (if required) Weather normalization rules followed

10.6 Safety Validations Battery not charging below freezing Transformer not overloaded Humidity and temperature not violated for HVAC reset EV charging not permitted beyond thermal envelope Lighting levels not below safety threshold

10.7 Stacking Validations No double counting No interaction omission Proper adjustment factors applied Battery DR reduces arbitrage Lighting reduces HVAC savings proportionally

10.8 Comfort Validations SAT reset not violating occupant cooling limits DCV not reducing ventilation below minimum Temperature drift acceptable for HVAC DR

10.9 Final Validation Output Validation must return:

Pass/Fail List of violations List of warnings List of recommended fixes Confidence rating

If validation fails, AI must NOT produce final savings.
